I'm supposed to be doing a lot of things right now. To name a few: my taxes, thank you notes, and homework.

Instead, I am reading Red Wings blogs, because I like to see what people are saying about the playoffs. And...I am reading really old entries in some of them. The Scrappy Octopus (best name ever?) was writing Valentine's Day poems (for...Valentine's Day. duh?) as various players.

I nearly cried reading this one and figured it warranted a post.

Pavel Datsyuk:
Roses are red,
Violets are blue,
I trust my eyes to Dr. Rahmani,
You should, too.

http://thescrappyoctopus.blogspot.com/2010/02/leftover-valentines-candy.html

Sooooo, it's exam week. And instead of studying or working on any of the FIVE essays I have due between now and Thursday...I decide it's more important to go meet Brett Lebda and Justin Abdelkader. There were only like...four people there in front of me, so I scurry up and stand in line. When I got up to them, I was pretty nervous, because I was starstruck I guess. We had this thrilling conversation. Me: Hi, can I get a picture? Brett: Yeah, of course! Wait, do you want to be in it? Me: YEAH. So I hand my camera to some random lady and she takes this gem: Brett: I'm pretty sure that was only my feet. Take 2 was much more successful: Then I had them sign a program I threw in my purse at the last minute (it was from the game they played against Boston a month or so ago, haha) but my hands were shaking so much that I was having trouble getting to the right pages, haha. They were both like "Oh, take your time" and "don't be nervous!" which just made things worse. And I remembered at the last minute to tell Justin that my bff goes to State and was really jealous that she didn't get to come meet him, and he told me to tell her hi. And I used my 15% off on a shot glass because I'm classy and ALMOST 21.

I really need this semester to be over with ASAP, because I really, really hate it. Two-thirds of my classes are useless now, because I changed my major last month. I'm unmotivated to do anything in these two classes. And the one class that actually counts towards something (history, which I'm minoring in) is pretty boring. Here's hoping next semester is better.

So, Thanksgiving is next week. 
I work in a "specialty" grocery store. I work the day before Thanksgiving. I can only imagine how crazy it's going to be. The day before Thanksgiving is like, the black Friday of the grocery store world. It's going to be interesting.
I was planning on going to the Wings game that night with Britt (yayyyyyyyy for the best friend coming home from college for the weekend!), but I honestly have no idea what time I'll even get out of work. Coworkers who have been there for 5+ years have been telling me that you can work anywhere from your regularly scheduled hours to 3-5 hours overtime. Yikes.

I wrote the shittiest paper for my prose fiction class the other day. My teacher passed it back today with full credit and positive comments. I fucking rock.

Actually, I shouldn't be too happy, because apparently my class is stupid.
Actual conversation in class today:
Teacher: What do you think about the author's use of the word "imprint" in that sentence? Does it fit?
Girl: No. She didn't even use it right.
Teacher: Oh? 
Girl: Imprint doesn't mean what she used it to mean.
Teacher: [sarcastic] It doesn't? What does it mean?
Girl: Imprinting is when you see the person you're gonna be with forever. You know, your soul mate.
Teacher: No, no it doesn't mean that.
Girl: Yuh huh! I read it in a book, it's a NATIVE AMERICAN term.
Teacher: ...

I wanted to tell her that Twilight isn't real and that Stephenie Meyer is probably not an accurate source of information, but I didn't want to admit to the class that I read the books.

So, I don't understand this story at all. Some guy SHOT another guy for talking during The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. I saw that movie last night, and truth be told, if I was going to shoot anyone during that movie, it would've been myself. Who thought making a 3 hour movie out of a 7 page short story was a good idea? It was such a snoozefest. And no, haters, I didn't "not get it." I got it. I just thought it was really long and drawn out. If it had been 90 minutes...it  would have been awesome. But not three hours.

I lost my paycheck last night. I fail at life.
